articles.headline: Abuse Scandal in Germany Edges Closer to Pope
articles.snippet: A church official acknowledged a German archdiocese made “serious mistakes” in reassigning an abusive priest during the pope’s tenure as its archbishop in the 1980s.
articles.abstract: A church official acknowledged a German archdiocese made “serious mistakes” in reassigning an abusive priest during the pope’s tenure as its archbishop in the 1980s.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A widening child sexual abuse inquiry in Europe has landed at the doorstep of Pope Benedict XVI, as a senior church official acknowledged Friday that a German archdiocese made “serious mistakes” in handling an abuse case while the pope served as its archbishop.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Kulish and Rachel Donadio

articles.headline: Obama Focuses on 3 to Fill Fed Board
articles.snippet: Issues like inflation and interest rate policy played roles in the administration putting forth names like Janet L. Yellen to be considered for the bank’s board of governors.
articles.abstract: Issues like inflation and interest rate policy played roles in the administration putting forth names like Janet L. Yellen to be considered for the bank’s board of governors.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Moving quickly to put its mark on the Federal Reserve, the White House on Friday identified two economists and a lawyer as its candidates to fill three seats on the central bank’s board of governors.

articles.headline: Pakistan Army Digs In on Turf of the Taliban
articles.snippet: The army has gained the upper hand, but insurgents in South Waziristan continue to make their presence known.
articles.abstract: The army has gained the upper hand, but insurgents in South Waziristan continue to make their presence known.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAKEEN, Pakistan — From a forward base in the bare brown foothills of the soaring mountains of South Waziristan, Pakistani soldiers fired artillery at insurgents sheltering in scrub across the valley. Smoke blotted the sky as the soldiers set ablaze houses once used by the Taliban to hide caches of heavy weapons.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and Pir Zubair Shah

articles.headline: Overdraft Protection: Why Bother?
articles.snippet: Many bank customers are having to decide whether to ask for overdraft protection. Most should say no.
articles.abstract: Many bank customers are having to decide whether to ask for overdraft protection. Most should say no.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many millions of people will face important choices about their checking and credit card accounts in the coming months, though this week one of the biggest banks made one of the decisions for them.

articles.headline: As Its Arms Makers Falter, Russia Buys Abroad
articles.snippet: Once-legendary Russian weapons are suffering embarrassing quality problems, and Russia’s own military is in talks with France to buy assault ships.
articles.abstract: Once-legendary Russian weapons are suffering embarrassing quality problems, and Russia’s own military is in talks with France to buy assault ships.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Ask a Russian what the country makes well, and the answer, more often than not, will be the Kalashnikov rifle.

articles.headline: Tea Party Avoids Divisive Social Issues
articles.snippet: God, life and family get little mention in the party’s statements, with the focus instead on fiscal responsibility.
articles.abstract: God, life and family get little mention in the party’s statements, with the focus instead on fiscal responsibility.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, faith and family have been at the center of the conservative movement. But as the Tea Party infuses conservatism with new energy, its leaders deliberately avoid discussion of issues like gay marriage or abortion.

articles.headline: Effort to Widen U.S. Internet Access Sets Up Battle
articles.snippet: The 10-year plan would reimagine the nation’s media and technology priorities by establishing high-speed Internet as the country’s dominant communication network.
articles.abstract: The 10-year plan would reimagine the nation’s media and technology priorities by establishing high-speed Internet as the country’s dominant communication network.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Communications Commission is proposing an ambitious 10-year plan that will reimagine the nation’s media and technology priorities by establishing high-speed Internet as the country’s dominant communication network.
articles.byline: By Brian Stelter and Jenna Wortham

articles.headline: Violations Are Cited in Generics
articles.snippet: Ranbaxy Laboratories, a maker of generic drugs, has run afoul of the Food and Drug Administration for violations at its United States factory in upstate New York.
articles.abstract: Ranbaxy Laboratories, a maker of generic drugs, has run afoul of the Food and Drug Administration for violations at its United States factory in upstate New York.
articles.lead_paragraph: As American consumers increasingly turn to generic drugs as a way to reduce their medical costs, the continued manufacturing problems of one generic maker stand out.

articles.headline: Findings on Lehman Take Even Experts by Surprise
articles.snippet: The report on the demise of Lehman Brothers is full of exhaustive detail in its nine volumes, acting as a road map for further inquiry into Lehman executives.
articles.abstract: The report on the demise of Lehman Brothers is full of exhaustive detail in its nine volumes, acting as a road map for further inquiry into Lehman executives.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the year that it took the court-appointed examiner to complete his report on the demise of Lehman Brothers, officials from Wall Street to Washington were anticipating it as the definitive account of the largest bankruptcy in American history.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Fed Helped Bank Raise Cash Quickly
articles.snippet: Lehman Brothers engaged in a series of transactions with the New York Fed that were similar to the ones that drew criticism from the bankruptcy court examiner who investigated its collapse.
articles.abstract: Lehman Brothers engaged in a series of transactions with the New York Fed that were similar to the ones that drew criticism from the bankruptcy court examiner who investigated its collapse.
articles.lead_paragraph: They were considered the dregs of Lehman Brothers — “bottom of the barrel,” as one banker put it.

articles.headline: Fearing Drug Cartels, Reporters in Mexico Retreat
articles.snippet: Attacks on the media along the border with the U.S. have resulted in what amounts to a news blackout.
articles.abstract: Attacks on the media along the border with the U.S. have resulted in what amounts to a news blackout.
articles.lead_paragraph: REYNOSA, Mexico — The big philosophical question in this gritty border town does not concern trees falling in the forest but bodies falling on the concrete: Does a shootout actually happen if the newspapers print nothing about it, the radio and television stations broadcast nothing, and the authorities never confirm that it occurred?

articles.headline: New Fraud Cases Point to Lapses in Iraq Projects
articles.snippet: Chaos, weak oversight and wide use of cash payments in the Iraq reconstruction program allowed Americans who took bribes to get off scot-free.
articles.abstract: Chaos, weak oversight and wide use of cash payments in the Iraq reconstruction program allowed Americans who took bribes to get off scot-free.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investigators looking into corruption involving reconstruction in Iraq say they have opened more than 50 new cases in six months by scrutinizing large cash transactions — involving banks, land deals, loan payments, casinos and even plastic surgery — made by some of the Americans involved in the nearly $150 billion program.

articles.headline: In Hard Times, Lured Into Trade School and Debt
articles.snippet: Commercial trade schools are under fire because they are attracting more students and Pell grants.
articles.abstract: Commercial trade schools are under fire because they are attracting more students and Pell grants.
articles.lead_paragraph: One fast-growing American industry has become a conspicuous beneficiary of the recession: for-profit colleges and trade schools.

articles.headline: Parliamentarian in Role as Health Bill Referee
articles.snippet: As the health care drama enters its final act, Alan S. Frumin, the Senate parliamentarian, is in a starring role.
articles.abstract: As the health care drama enters its final act, Alan S. Frumin, the Senate parliamentarian, is in a starring role.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the fall of 1968, a serious dark-haired young man arrived in the capital to do what serious young men here do: study law. Alan S. Frumin was calm, analytical and possessed of a dry wit. To his classmates, one trait stood out. He was a whiz at mastering the mind-numbing rules of civil procedure.

articles.headline: Apple’s Spat With Google Is Getting Personal
articles.snippet: Once allies, Steve Jobs and Eric Schmidt are now engaged in a gritty fight over mobile computing and cellphones.
articles.abstract: Once allies, Steve Jobs and Eric Schmidt are now engaged in a gritty fight over mobile computing and cellphones.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT looked like the beginning of a beautiful friendship.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Miguel Helft

articles.headline: Private Equity’s Trojan Horse of Debt
articles.snippet: In the Wind Hellas deal in Greece, the Texas Pacific Group and Apax Partners came out on top. Some who bought the company’s debt have not.
articles.abstract: In the Wind Hellas deal in Greece, the Texas Pacific Group and Apax Partners came out on top. Some who bought the company’s debt have not.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHENEVER savvy private equity firms sell debt in the companies they own, buyer beware.

articles.headline: Great Time to Buy (Famous Last Words)
articles.snippet: One real estate broker has this advice for prospective homebuyers: “Predicting interest rates is a whole lot easier than predicting home prices.”
articles.abstract: One real estate broker has this advice for prospective homebuyers: “Predicting interest rates is a whole lot easier than predicting home prices.”
articles.lead_paragraph: “IT’S a great time to buy a home.”

articles.headline: Out of Ruin, Haiti’s Visionaries
articles.snippet: Many of Haiti’s museums were damaged in the country’s earthquake, but an exhibition scheduled there for 2012 hopes to revive the fortunes of the country’s creators.
articles.abstract: Many of Haiti’s museums were damaged in the country’s earthquake, but an exhibition scheduled there for 2012 hopes to revive the fortunes of the country’s creators.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a disaster, you focus on lives first, all else later. When the earthquake hit Haiti in January, the news was about the dead and missing, miraculous survivals, towns smashed to bits.

articles.headline: The Thrill of Science, Tamed by Agendas
articles.snippet: Science museums experiment in their struggle to define themselves.
articles.abstract: Science museums experiment in their struggle to define themselves.
articles.lead_paragraph: A science museum is a kind of experiment. It demands the most elaborate equipment: Imax theaters, NASA space vehicles, collections of living creatures, digital planetarium projectors, fossilized bones. Into this mix are thrust tens of thousands of living human beings: children on holiday, weary or eager parents, devoted teachers, passionate aficionados and casual passers-by. And the experimenters watch, test, change, hoping. ...

articles.headline: The New Guard of Curators Steps Up
articles.snippet: Far from the stereotype of fusty academics, curators in their 30s and 40s are bringing eclectic backgrounds and a fresh eye to Manhattan’s museums.
articles.abstract: Far from the stereotype of fusty academics, curators in their 30s and 40s are bringing eclectic backgrounds and a fresh eye to Manhattan’s museums.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE mouth of a giant monster, its razor-sharp teeth glaring overhead and its tongue forming a long red carpet, ushers visitors into the Tim Burton retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art. Although the intentionally lighthearted chronicle of the filmmaker’s work received only mixed reviews when it opened in November, Mr. Burton’s fans don’t seem to care. More than 450,000 people have already attended the show, and by the time it closes on April 26, attendance is expected to exceed that of recent blockbusters like the museum’s “Van Gogh: The Colors of the Night” last year and “Dali: Painting and Film,” in 2008.

articles.headline: Two Drug Slayings in Mexico Rock U.S. Consulate
articles.snippet: The White House responded angrily to deadly attacks that appeared to be the first on U.S. officials and their families by Mexico’s drug cartels.
articles.abstract: The White House responded angrily to deadly attacks that appeared to be the first on U.S. officials and their families by Mexico’s drug cartels.
articles.lead_paragraph: LA UNIÓN, Mexico — Gunmen believed to be linked to drug traffickers shot a pregnant American consulate worker and her husband to death in the violence-racked border town of Ciudad Juárez over the weekend, leaving their baby wailing in the back seat of their car, the authorities said Sunday. The gunmen also killed the husband of another consular employee and wounded his two young children.
articles.byline: By Marc Lacey and Ginger Thompson

articles.headline: With Financial Reform Bill, a Test for Congress
articles.snippet: Senate Democrats are ready to introduce legislation meant to overhaul the nation’s financial system while trying to overcome partisanship.
articles.abstract: Senate Democrats are ready to introduce legislation meant to overhaul the nation’s financial system while trying to overcome partisanship.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats will press forward this week on legislation to overhaul the nation’s financial system in a critical test of whether Washington can pass reform.

articles.headline: Saving U.S. Water and Sewer Systems Would Be Costly
articles.snippet: Ruptures in aging water systems cause pollutants to seep into water supplies, but in many cities residents have protested rate increases to fix pipes.
articles.abstract: Ruptures in aging water systems cause pollutants to seep into water supplies, but in many cities residents have protested rate increases to fix pipes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One recent morning, George S. Hawkins, a long-haired environmentalist who now leads one of the largest and most prominent water and sewer systems, trudged to a street corner here where water was gushing into the air.

articles.headline: China Uses Rules on Global Trade to Its Advantage
articles.snippet: Beijing uses inconsistencies in international trade rules to spur its own economy at the expense of others.
articles.abstract: Beijing uses inconsistencies in international trade rules to spur its own economy at the expense of others.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — With China’s exports soaring, even as other major economies struggle to recover from the recession, evidence is mounting that Beijing is skillfully using inconsistencies in international trade rules to spur its own economy at the expense of others, including the United States.

articles.headline: Telling Friends Where You Are (or Not)
articles.snippet: Giving people more choices in revealing their locations with their cellphones is being popularized by the Foursquare service.
articles.abstract: Giving people more choices in revealing their locations with their cellphones is being popularized by the Foursquare service.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — As Jordan Viator roams the conference rooms, dimly lit bars and restaurants here at the South by Southwest Interactive conference, she often pulls out her cellphone and uses the Foursquare service to broadcast her location.

articles.headline: Trade Papers Struggling in Hollywood
articles.snippet: Waning ad revenue and increasing competition on the Web raise the question if entertainment trade papers like Variety and The Hollywood Reporter can survive.
articles.abstract: Waning ad revenue and increasing competition on the Web raise the question if entertainment trade papers like Variety and The Hollywood Reporter can survive.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Variety, the show business bible, was born nearly 105 years ago when young Sime Silverman, by his own account, was fired by The Morning Telegraph for a review in which he declared a new theatrical sketch by a performer who happened to be one of the paper’s advertisers “N. G. (No Good).”
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: A Cable Power’s Global Reach
articles.snippet: Discovery Communications is well positioned in cable TV, analysts say, because it owns most of its shows and can cheaply replay them in dozens of countries.
articles.abstract: Discovery Communications is well positioned in cable TV, analysts say, because it owns most of its shows and can cheaply replay them in dozens of countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch’s deputy, Chase Carey, looked out on the cable television landscape last fall and found a rival he wanted to emulate. Discovery Communications, he said, is “a road map of where I’d like to be.”

articles.headline: Talking Back to Your TV, Incessantly
articles.snippet: With social media, a traditionally passive form of entertainment could someday become a conglomeration of professional production and multiple conversations.
articles.abstract: With social media, a traditionally passive form of entertainment could someday become a conglomeration of professional production and multiple conversations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Back in 1988, Joel Hodgson, a funny guy in Minneapolis, came up with a local television show called “Mystery Science Theater 3000.” In the goofy plot, a janitor was launched into space by a couple of evil scientists and marooned there, forced to watch an endless run of exceptionally bad B-movies.

articles.headline: Deal Is Near for the Sale of Hilfiger
articles.snippet: Phillips-Van Heusen, the clothing conglomerate that owns Calvin Klein, is near a deal to buy Tommy Hilfiger for about $3 billion.
articles.abstract: Phillips-Van Heusen, the clothing conglomerate that owns Calvin Klein, is near a deal to buy Tommy Hilfiger for about $3 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Phillips-Van Heusen, the clothing conglomerate that owns Calvin Klein, is near a deal to buy Tommy Hilfiger, once a leading purveyor of colorful preppy clothing, for about 2.2 billion euros, or $3 billion, in cash and stock, people briefed on the matter said Sunday night.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Contractors Tied to Effort to Track and Kill Militants
articles.snippet: A Defense Department official set up a private network of spies in Pakistan and Afghanistan to gather intelligence on insurgents, according to officials.
articles.abstract: A Defense Department official set up a private network of spies in Pakistan and Afghanistan to gather intelligence on insurgents, according to officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Under the cover of a benign government information-gathering program, a Defense Department official set up a network of private contractors in Afghanistan and Pakistan to help track and kill suspected militants, according to military officials and businessmen in Afghanistan and the United States.
articles.byline: By Dexter Filkins and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Israel Feeling Rising Anger From the U.S.
articles.snippet: An ill-timed housing announcement has left the Israeli government scrambling to respond to a tough list of demands by the Obama administration.
articles.abstract: An ill-timed housing announcement has left the Israeli government scrambling to respond to a tough list of demands by the Obama administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An ill-timed municipal housing announcement in Jerusalem has mutated into one of the most serious conflicts between the United States and Israel in two decades, leaving a politically embarrassed Israeli government scrambling to respond to a tough list of demands by the Obama administration.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Ethan Bronner

articles.headline: Defibrillator Sales Halted by a Maker
articles.snippet: The company withdraws the heart devices, saying it failed to warn the Food and Drug Administration about manufacturing changes.
articles.abstract: The company withdraws the heart devices, saying it failed to warn the Food and Drug Administration about manufacturing changes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Boston Scientific vowed when it acquired Guidant in 2006 for $27 billion that it would rebuild the troubled producer of implantable heart defibrillators into a new model of industry safety and public transparency.
